Articles.Content: Perhaps I don't understand what you're talking about. The gauge is always relative to your ship's up vector. This is not aligned to the camera unless you enter chase mode by hitting v, but that is a function of the game and not the mod.
I don't get what is your problem either, the roll vector is always aligned to be "Up" with respect to the ship... And it works flawlessly for me too
Maybe Miro has placed the target docking port on the target ship at an angle?

That's not it either. The gauge aligns to the targeted docking port, so it doesn't matter how that port is oriented on the targeted ship. And as long as you select control from here, the gauge is perfectly aligned to your controlling ship's docking port.

I think he's confused by the fact that up on the gauge is not necessarily up on the screen, but that will be resolved if be uses chase cam.

Edited November 6, 2015 by NavyFish

That's not it either. The gauge aligns to the targeted docking port, so it doesn't matter how that port is oriented on the targeted ship. And as long as you select control from here, the gauge is perfectly aligned to your controlling ship's docking port.

Doesn't the orientation of the target port affect the roll indicator?

The symptoms sound like those of trying to dock without using "locked" mode on the camera, not really related to DPAI.

Yes, and yes.

The gauge will line things up so two ports mate face to face with each others 'up' vectors aligned - ie on a clamp o tron, the yellow handle is considered to be in the 'up' direction relative to the port's center.

Perhaps he wants it so that the ports are naturally mated at a different roll alignment, which is not an option in the mod, but the same effect can be achieved by rotating thhe target port in the editor. Still, I think that chase cam is what he's looking for.

Maybe I am just doing things old school before the docking port was invented.... Lets say you have a long tube as a ship and off the side of it in dead center you have a port.

Now lets say you have two of them in space.

So when you doc the two of them up... you can technically dock them aligned so from a horizontal view they will look aligned like the letter "I" or you can dock them so they will look like an "X"

Now lets say the two piece have to be docked aligned or it wont be weighted properly in space.

The problem I always have is that when I start rotating the ships around the rcs gets all messed up. Up becomes down and down becomes up. I would like to specify my docking port (control from here) [this I can do], I would like to specify "target port" [this I can do].... but when I rotate the ship around, I would like to specify which way is "up down left right" on my rcs so I can properly align stuff in space.
